title: Thursday, 15th September, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE

Morning, then. Hi. Welcome to Thursday.

BE

And here, have a picture.

BE

11:04 am
BE

That's the Fancy Bears Hack Team website.

BE

Currently living prominently on the FT homepage: https://www.ft.com...-ae24-f193b105145e

BE

The World Anti-Doping Agency has confirmed that a second batch of medical files relating to athletes who competed at the Rio Olympics has been leaked by a Russian hacking group, including those of medals winners such as Britain’s Chris Froome and Sir Bradley Wiggins.

On Thursday, a group calling itself Fancy Bears’ Hack Team followed up its release of information relating to three US Olympians, with a wider data dump in connection with 25 athletes from eight countries.

11:05 am
BE

............ But not accessible from within the FT offices.

BE

Firewalls suck, right? They never bloody work. Never ever ever.

BE

So it's great news that we're going to have a national one: https://www.ft.com...-97ae-647294649b28

11:06 am
BE

Ambitious new plans are being drawn up by GCHQ to create a “Great British Firewall” to block malicious websites countrywide and combat a doubling of serious cyber attacks threatening national security over the past year.

Though still in its infancy, the scheme is intended to be a flagship project for the new National Cyber Security Centre — a public-facing arm of GCHQ which will open next month to better co-ordinate the UK’s digital defence efforts.

The NCSC plan envisions private-sector internet service providers, such as BT, Sky or Virgin Media, voluntarily complying with its proposals, circumventing any need for legislation. Consumers will be able to opt out of the censorship should they wish in order to allay concerns over civil liberties.

BE

I'm totally down with the idea of having NCSC and or BT, Sky and Virgin Media choosing what sites I can access.

BE

And I'm not seeing it in any way connected to yesterday's waffle about the rather structural threat of Sky getting Napstered, as noted at the end of yesterday's show.

11:09 am
BE

But anyway, let's move on to the proper stuff.

undefined
BE

FTSE up a tad, but it's a rather mixed market.

11:10 am
BE

With Next, clearly, the main problem.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,927, down 283 (-5.43%), High: 5,165, Low: 4,915, Volume: 549.35k
BE

Trading remains "challenging and volatile" .....

11:11 am
BE

Retail getting worse, directories holding steady.

BE

There's no explicit change to guidance though.

BE

Let me chuck up Credit Suisse to summarise things

11:12 am
BE

Recent trading remains challenging: The key takeaway from the Next
results is the commentary on recent trading. July sales strength was driven
by a larger end of season sale (1H markdown impact on margin: -180bps)
while full price sales were subdued. Trading in August was 'challenging and
volatile' which we assume was due to unusually warm weather (as also seen
in H&M's statement today). On that basis the outlook for September is even
worse, giving yet another poor start to A/W. On the positive side the FY
revised outlook from august remains unchanged.

BE

1H PBT of £342m (vs £362m) and £5m better than our £337m forecast.
Retail margins were down 2.5ppt Y/Y mainly driven by the higher markdown
while Directory margin (+90bps Y/Y) was helped by higher interest income.
Active customers were +5% driven by higher cash customer numbers while
active credit accounts were down 4% as recruiting new customers became
increasingly difficult. Average balance per credit customer edged higher to
£403 and we look for comments at the meeting on the latest initiatives to
stabilize credit accounts including interest free options on big ticket.

BE

Other highlights: New store openings were pulled forward with this year
delivering 350K sqft (vs 275K). The impact of sterling weakness on input
costs is expected to be 5% next year and the company implied price rises to
come to protect margins, which would be in line with the past. However
whether this succeeds in a soft and deflationary environment is debatable.

11:13 am
BE

The DPS was flat as expected and there is no increase in the expected
buyback. We still believe that Next is ex-growth because margins are
too high and the credit book is over-earning. We would not expect to
change forecasts but remain well below consensus for outer years. We
retain our Neutral rating.

BE

And Jefferies ........

BE

Detail: Next sets a cautionary tone on the demand outlook, reiterating the trend away
from buying clothing towards spending on leisure experiences like going out and holidays.
However, Next believes that the sourcing pressure in 2017/18 will be only c.-5% and that,
in contrast to Primark, it is better to pass this inflation on and suffer a c.5.5% hit to volumes
rather than take a margin hit. Next is also upping its space growth as one of the few ways to "mitigate losses from negative LFL sales".

11:14 am
BE

[W]ith a cautionary comment that full price trading has been weak since June
and they will give further guidance in Nov. The shares have had a good recovery post-Brexit
(+18%) and are trading on 12.2x cal 17 EPS for zero EPS CAGR and 3% yield.

BE

Now I know anecdote isn't data, but I've had two or three occasions to drift into Next over the past month.

BE

And it seemed pricier than I remembered. More mid-level, M&S pricing rather than H&M.

11:17 am
BE

This is just a suspicion, but might I be right to think Next's catalogue business is rather less price sensitive than high street retail and it's the former that's now being used as the benchmark?

BE

Next Furniture, for instance, makes no sense. It's damn expensive. Priced at John Lewis--plus. But I guess most of it's bought on HP.

BE

Morgan Stanley too? Sure.

11:18 am
BE

- Next had already issued a 2Q trading update, so the H1 earnings numbers were
never likely to surprise much today. Indeed they have not (Pre Tax Profits have
come in at £341m, versus a bloomberg consensus average of £341m).
- The key, today, we believe is the tone of the statement. Whereas Next used its
Preliminary Results in March to warn the market of a very tough outlook, the
tone of today's statement appears much more neutral (although its is probably
fair to say that Next's message is little changed - it is just that market
expectations are now very different).

BE

- As usual with Next, there is a detailed operational and strategic update. On first
read, however, it doesn’t appear to contain many surprises. Probably the most
interesting comments relate to the FX headwinds that the company will face
next year (which management estimates will impact input costs by no more than
5%) and what Next proposes to do to counter them (the statement is very clear
that the company will put up selling prices where necessary)
- Back in July the company tightened its profit guidance range for the year to
£775m-£845m. The company has re-iterated this today, though is flagging that
current trading has been "challenging and volatile" and that it expects to have a
clearer view when it reports its FYQ3 trading update at the beginning of
November. According to Bloomberg the consensus average Pre Tax Profit
expectation is currently £803m and we would not anticipate this moving much
today.

BE

- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Next is
trading on 11.7x earnings, 8.9x EBITDA with a 3.3% Dividend Yield. This compares
with a UK General Retail sector trading on 13.2x, 8.2x and 3.6% respectively

11:19 am
BE

(@ROTR: it's a wee bit uncomfortable when you talk about me. I'm only over here.)

undefined
BE

Sector wise, predictable response.

11:20 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 313.67, down 8.13 (-2.53%), High: 319.40, Low: 307.70, Volume: 4.68m
Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 57.15, down 0.7 (-1.21%), High: 58.30, Low: 56.85, Volume: 491.59k
BE

Oh, and Sports Direct.

11:20 am
Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 287.70, down 18.5 (-6.04%), High: 302.30, Low: 286.00, Volume: 1.97m
BE

Citi's downgraded.

BE

For the same reasons Peel Hunt upgraded for at the end of last week.

11:21 am
BE

Those reasons being that Sports Direct needs to reinvent its business model, of using Nike trainers as bait to sell Lonsdale.

BE

Peel Hunt -- in an excellent note, I'd argue -- saw this realisation as a Damascene moment for Ashley and turned buyer.

BE

Citi now goes, "aye, but what about margins."

11:23 am
BE

Structural changes and fashion cycle working against Sports Direct
We increasingly suspect that the growth of online retailers selling branded sportswear and the increasing sales of sportswear across diverse apparel retailers (as the fashion cycle currently favours sportswear) are reducing the pull factor of Sports Direct stores. This is could partly explain why Sports Direct is moving to larger format stores to meet the more demanding requirements of the Sportswear brands and change a business model that has worked for 30 years. The timing and success of this change is uncertain.

BE

Near term profits under pressure
A combination of weak current trading, a negative 275bps gross margin headwind from fx movements and cost inflation has forced Sports Direct to cut its guidance for FY17E EBITDA to c.£300m. For reference, this compares to our forecast of £425m at the start of the year. Given current weakness in the UK apparel market and uncertainty about UK consumer cashflow, combined with Sport Direct’s willingness to sacrifice near term profit to maintain the consumer proposition, we think there is unlikely to be a near term rebound in profitability.

BE

Larger format store strategy creates uncertain profitability profile while tying up capital
Sports Direct has guided that it will spend up to £300m per year on the acquisition of freehold properties. While it is too early to fully analyse the return that will be made on this capital, the group ROCE is certain to fall in at least the near term. The longer term implications remain unclear.

11:23 am
BE

30% cuts to forecast, FY17e PBT £171m (EPS 23.8p, -33% yoy)
We cut our FY17e underlying EBITDA to £305m to be aligned with £300m guidance. On our forecasts, net debt/EBITDA increases to 1.5x by FY19e (3.6x lease-adjusted).

BE

Cut to Neutral rating , TP 340p
In light of the forecast cuts we strike our Target Price on 12.5x FY18e EV/EBIT. This is underpinned by a 350p DCF valuation that incorporates a 6.0% EBIT margin, against the 5.6% that we forecast for FY17e and the 10.7% that was achieved in FY15.

undefined
11:26 am
BE

Right, what else do we have?

BE

Not quite sure what to say yet about RSA.

RSA Insurance Group PLC (RSA:LSE): Last: 519.06, up 10.06 (+1.98%), High: 520.18, Low: 506.00, Volume: 1.14m
11:27 am
BE

Live up 2.1% ..... Volume about twice the average.

BE

Last night's auction featured a big buyer (or buyers).

BE

....... and there was some talk through the summer about the longer term strategic options and when Hester might consider his job done.

11:30 am
BE

If anyone wants a chat about that, they'll probably know how to contact me. In the meantime, I just note it.

undefined
BE

Morrison mentioned on the right.

11:30 am
BE

(@Soundbuy: you're right, nearly three times average. Haven't heard a story though.)

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 208.42, up 14.82 (+7.66%), High: 211.00, Low: 202.50, Volume: 28.20m
BE

Half-year LFL sales beat by a bit, at 1.4%. Consensus was about 1% I think.

11:32 am
BE

Underlying profit also above.

BE

Though note, it's not on trading.

BE

Here's Barclays.

11:33 am
BE

· Underlying EBIT of £207m was c3% above our estimate of £201mn and underlying PBT (Morrison definition) came in c4-5% ahead of our and consensus estimate (from Vuma) of £150mn.

BE

Net debt: £1,269mn, versus Barclays £1,584mn
· Working capital was the main contributor to the net debt reduction, with the increase in creditors particularly strong in 1H16 at £324mn, even higher than it was for the whole of 2015/16 and three times the level of the comparable half.

BE

Looking forwards, there is nothing significantly new from an operational perspective, but the company gave very positive guidance on cost savings and cash going forward: i) will exceed the £1bn cost savings target over three years ending this financial year; ii) the £2bn FCF target over the same time frame than has been exceeded with six months left; iii) Working capital inflow target increased from £800m to £1bn “over the medium-term”; iv) Current year net debt target lowered from £1.4-1.5bn to c£1.2bn and to below £1bn by end 17/18.

· Overall, 1H results were clearly strong on sales and profits, while the cash performance and outlook seems exceptionally strong. However, we are interested to learn more about the sustainability of the creditor flows and we are also skeptical that Morrison is likely to feel confident enough to return cash anytime soon given industry uncertainties - but clearly its potential to do so is increasing.

11:34 am
BE

And Morgan Stanley (again)

BE

Bottom line: This was a solid trading update by Morrisons, both at the top and
bottom line level. However, Kantar data shows that Morrisons has clearly
benefited from Asda's big decline during the period. Going forward, we expect
Asda to invest in its customer proposition and the UK market and Morrison will
continue to have to cope with numerous structural headwinds, such as adverse
CPI-PPI spread post Brexit, a 15%+ price gap to discounters, continued imbalance
in supply/demand, cost base inflation (minimum wage, rents / business rates,
etc.), and market polarization.

BE

Profit: Overall, underlying PBT came in at £159m in 1H17, which compares to last
year's £147m (the clean recurring number); This is lower than Morgan Stanley's
estimates (£161m) but higher than consensus number, which stood at £149m.
Despite Tesco increasing the pricing pressure at the low-end of the fresh/produce
segment (through its Farm Brands initiative), Morrison's gross margin remained
resilient in H1, partially helped by efficiency measures in procurement, sourcing
and promotions and by Asda, we think, having continued to protect its P&L (see
No sign of Asda tackling its pricing).
Of note, Morrison did announce new series of price cuts only after its Q2 (on 1
August, Morrison said it cut prices of more than 1,000 products by an average 18% and on
September 4th it announced that it was reducing the price of 130 essential meat
and poultry products and more than 30 fruit vegetables).
Company gathered consensus for FY17 underlying PBT is currently £313m. On
the back of today's release, we would expect a very small increase to
~£315m/320m.

11:37 am
BE

(@Damaging: while not disagreeing with your thesis, grocery deflation seems a very complicated theme that evades simple explanations.)

BE

(@Blue Horseshoe: I admire your persistence, if nothing else.)

undefined
11:38 am
BE

Oh, and while on the sector, Credit Suisse has written response to the excellent Exane Ocado note we shared yesterday.

BE

We believe we are in a transitionary period for food retail.

BE

Transitioning from bad to worse, one might argue.

11:39 am
BE

Traditional grocery stores are
working to solve challenging store economics with non-food and concessions amidst a
steady bleeding of market share. For Ocado, technology and scale provide a path to lower
costs and increased efficiency. We reject the views that Ocado has not yet seen the
benefits of either, or that those benefits won't continue into the future.
We have already seen a steady improvement in CFC economics, which were based on
incremental changes to first-generation technology1. We expect picking efficiency to rise
markedly once CFC 3 in Andover is commissioned this autumn.
Longer term, we still see multiple paths to materially higher margins through improved
picking efficiency (further automation, robotics and other materials handling advances),
higher drop densities, customised marketing, assortment expansion and even driverless
deliveries.

BE

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily whatever.

BE

Basket size moved down again, to £107.94 from £111.75 YoY (-3.4%), a trend that causes
some to be concerned about ongoing profitability. Ocado would certainly be more
profitable if basket sizes were much larger. But that is not what customers want, nor is it a
viable path to long-term profitability. While small baskets strain economics due to nearfixed
delivery costs, they also engender loyalty and spur membership in Ocado's (near
100% margin) Smart Pass program (~£70/year for mid-week deliveries and ~£110/year for
anytime deliveries). We view smaller basket sizes as a "normalisation" of online shopping.
It's not just "back from holidays", Christmas or party time. We expect Ocado to be able to
offset smaller basket sizes with continuous efficiency improvement in order to maintain
profitability.

11:41 am
BE

You get the idea.

undefined
BE

(@Damaging: that seems to make sense. What I struggle with is how to get a feel of what grocery margins should be. There's an argument what, pre the Lidl invasion, the big-four were making super-normal profits for several decades because they were taking share from the soft underbelly of small operators who buy their stuff from Booker.)

11:44 am
BE

What else, then?

BE

I think Sepura was mentioned somewhere near the start.

Sepura PLC (SEPU:LSE): Last: 11.25, down 0.75 (-6.25%), High: 13.00, Low: 10.00, Volume: 26.48m
11:45 am
BE

Colossal profit warning midway through yesterday.

BE

Sepura makes radios, for those who don't know. The type the police use.

BE

And it seems the police aren't upgrading their old kit.

11:46 am
BE

Forcing Sepura into talks with its lenders.

BE

Here's Liberum, which is shop.

BE

Expected orders have not materialised. The FY outlook to March has
significantly deteriorated. EBITDA guidance will be missed by c. 60%. The
CEO has stepped down for health reasons. The CFO is now acting CEO.
Extremely disappointing post the equity raising on 24 June to strengthen
the b/s. Sepura will need to discuss a waiver to y/e covenants. We place
our estimates, rec and TP under review. Following a preliminary approach
announced in July, their predicament may attract other potential acquirers.

11:47 am
BE

In an update released at 12 noon Sepura has revealed order intake in the last two and a half months has been below expectations. Reasons given are emerging delays in Device refresh opportunities, primarily through budget pressures and key contract awards in Systems being delayed. This relates to European and South American markets, while there has been progress in North America. As such, the latest pipeline and associated timings mean adj EBITDA to March 2017 is anticipated to be c. 60% below its previous expectations.
Underlying EBITDA guidance was previously €27m (Liberum €26.4m. Sepura* (BUY, TP 70p) - Resumption of Recommendation and TP (17 pgs)). Our prior FY forecast revenue was €204m (c 60% Devices and 40% Systems). The market is growing at 6% according to IHS. FY17 revenue is now expected to be around €160m, a €45m reduction. Gross margin was previously estimated at 42.5% from 40.5% last year. The margin increase was attributed to in-sourcing, withdrawing from DMR and completion of lower margin Saudi orders. Further significant savings are being targeted. Sepura currently has around 700 employees that cost c €50k/head.

BE

The Group has sufficient liquidity for its forecast needs but revised expectations will require Sepura to discuss with its lenders a possible waiver of certain covenants from March 2017. The year-end net debt/ebitda covenant is 3.5x. At first glance, this will reach 6x on downgraded expectations.

BE

SIX TIMES!

11:48 am
BE

That's emergency rights territory, yes?

BE

Which is tricky while ..............

BE

CEO Gordon Watling has received medical advice to take an immediate and extended period of absence, in order to recover fully from an accident earlier in the year. CFO Richard Smith has been appointed Acting CEO with immediate effect in addition to his existing responsibilities. On 16 August the company announced Chairman Russell King intends to step down once a replacement has been appointed, which is anticipated to be in the Autumn.

11:48 am
BE

............. And we wish Mr Watling a speedy recovery.

BE

Here's the straw Liberum's chosen to clutch at.

BE

On 28 July, Sepura announced they had received a preliminary approach from a third party which since stepped away. This aroused suspicions of other interest given Sepura’s large installed base in TETRA worldwide and foothold in the nascent North American market. The current position of weakness is likely to attract other potential trade and private equity interest.

11:50 am
undefined
BE

......... apologies, that brief pause was while I found something else to talk about.

BE

In terms of requests, Informa .......

11:52 am
Informa PLC (INF:LSE): Last: 711.00, up 17.5 (+2.52%), High: 725.00, Low: 697.00, Volume: 1.37m
BE

Buying Penton Information Services, a New York based B2B player

BE

For £1.2bn. To be funded by a £715m rights issue and debt

11:53 am
BE

£715m fully underwritten, one for four.

BE

Initial response seems to be fairly positive.

BE

Investec.

11:53 am
BE

A good strategic fit. Penton is a good strategic fit and will add scale to both the Informa Business Information division and Global Exhibitions with a smaller portion falling into Knowledge and Networking. This also expands Informa's US presence, a positive. In terms of Penton mix c.45% of revenue and 55% of profit will sit in Exhibitions, 45% of revenue and 35% of profit in Business Intelligence and 10% of revenue and profit in Knowledge & Networking.
Deal structure. The Sellers (including certain management alongside MidOcean Partners and Wasserrstein & Co) will receive £1.105bn consideration in cash and £76m in new Informa equity with a one year lock in. Pro-forma Informa management expect gearing post deal to be 2.6x at 31 December, so a little higher than ideal but very manageable given the strong cash generation of the Group. Requires shareholder approval. Implied transaction multiple of 11x EBITDA with an expected £14m of synergy and £18m of integration exceptional costs from combining the Groups. On this basis management believe it will be earnings enhancing in the first year of acquisition.
Strategically sensible fit, at face value sensible price, need to due diligence asset quality. So all in strategically a very good fit, good that they are increasing US exposure, multiple sensible (and below Informa), that all said we will need to do a little further due diligence to understand the quality of what they are buying. The level of expected EPS accretion will depend on tax charge and goodwill that is available to expense, at best on negligible tax on acquired profits it could be c.6% accretive to 2017 numbers. There is an analyst meeting at 9am this morning.

BE

AQnd Liberum, off the conference call.

BE

Informa's GE business has been growing ahead of the rest of the group at 10.5% organic growth vs 2.6% for the whole group. Management stated that putting their businesses in Informa terms that Penton's Events business was growing at a comparable rate to Informa's GE business in organic terms. Penton's Events revenues have been growing at a 21% CAGR between 2013-15, over the same period Events adj. operating profits have been growing at +20%.Informa expects geo-cloning of its newly enlarged GE business to be the major driver of the vertical.

Informa's BI renewal rates have been below industry standard, on the whole both businesses have been growing at similar rates with Penton maybe slightly ahead. The difference being Penton's renewal rates have been trending above industry standard, it would seem that there is some operational advantage that Informa can utilise

Penton's digital business has been growing at an 18% CAGR over 2013-15 and Print has been declining at 18%. Print revenues accounted for c.25% of Penton's revenues and print revenues will account for 6% of the enlarged groups revenues and 3% of adj. operating profit.

11:55 am
undefined
BE

Hargreaves, as noted on the right, is a Liberum downgrade.

Hargreaves Lansdown PLC (HL.:LSE): Last: 1,275, down 59.1 (-4.43%), High: 1,309, Low: 1,260, Volume: 476.46k
11:56 am
BE

Sell from buy.

BE

Analyst is Justin Bates, who explains himself in very short terms.

BE

There is no doubting the formidable track record and strength of the HL/ business model. However, trading on a PE of 36x, with the prospect of consensus downgrades and significant industry headwinds, we view the risk/reward as unfavourable. We estimate a further cut in the base rate, to 0.10%, would result in an additional 5% p.a. hit to EPS. Our forecasts are already 10% below consensus in FY18. The shares are +27% since late June. We move to SELL.

11:57 am
BE

FY16 results ahead

Vantage net inflows of £5.9bn were slightly weaker than expected but Adj. PBT was 4% ahead and EPS a 5% beat v’s Libf. Good cost control aided the result.

Industry headwinds

The possibility of further cuts to base rates, increased regulatory capital requirements, margin pressure and the FCA's review of the industry add up to a challenging outlook.

Interest income falling

We now forecast interest income turn of 0.40% in FY17 (Old. 0.53%), falling to 0.25% in FY18 & FY19. If the base rate is cut to 0.10% we expect a further 5% cut to EPS.

Move to SELL from Buy

Our revised EPS forecasts are 4% below consensus in FY17, 10% in FY18 and 13% in FY19. Our TP of 1176p = 13% d/side. We anticipate a more attractive entry point.

BE

BE

(It appears I've forgotten to select the "hide mouse pointer" option on ShareX.)

11:59 am
BE

And again, as noted on the right, Hargreaves is ex a 16.3p final and a 9.9p special.

undefined
BE

Will that do for today? I'm sure we're missing stuff, but I can't think of anything immediately.

12:00 pm
BE

Oh, wait!

BE

I meant to mention Purplebricks.

BE

The -- for want of a more accurate term -- hybrid estate agent.

12:01 pm
Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 136.00, up 6 (+4.62%), High: 139.00, Low: 133.00, Volume: 615.85k
BE

Trading update looks fine enough.

BE

No Brexit impact (as you'd expect) ... Trading "very encouraging" (as you'd expect)

12:03 pm
BE

Though the question remains .... what exactly does Purplebricks do?

BE

Does it sell houses?

BE

Or does it advertise houses to buyers who then go to a proper estate agent, rather than a freelance on impossible commission targets?

12:04 pm
BE

Investec reckons the former.

BE

We initiate at Buy. The estate agency market looks ripe for disruption given a slow digital transition, high fees and a high fixed cost base. Purplebricks can leverage online portal distribution with its platform-driven hybrid model to offer a superior low cost, high quality service. Combined with a strong national brand and B/S cash we see good scalability. Rapid instruction and sales growth to date proves customer appeal and disruptive potential. Our price target of 205p is based on scenario-weighted DCF (UK 189p/Australia 16p).

BE

Disrupting the incumbents. Low price/cost model undercuts traditional agencies while the tech platform gives transparency/control to vendors. Already the 4th largest UK agent by transactions (just 2 years post launch).
Stand-out challenger. Purplebricks’ hybrid Local Property Expert (LPE) offer (tech platform plus on-the-ground agents) is growing far faster than pure online models, also boosted by solid funding and a strong brand name.
UK market opportunity. We estimate 1% market share in FY16 rising to 3.6% share by FY19E implying £22m UK EBITDA (break-even FY17E). If share moved to 6%, our scenario analysis suggests c. +130% EPS upside.
Australia optionality. £10m investment to access a new high price market, but still early stage. Conservative forecasts imply 16p/share value.
Good sales conversion vs the industry. Though LPE’s are paid by instruction, the platform, the service culture and controls all drive sales. Our sampling shows greater than 50% agree a sale in 6 weeks. Purplebricks suggests over 77% of instructions won in Apr 15 - Mar 16 had a sale agreed by June 16.
Scalable model. We believe the LPE model can scale, while a proven/well invested technology platform plus fixed overhead implies good leverage and conversion to profit/cash.
Positive 1Q. On track for FY17 management expectations. 19 week trading is “very encouraging” - little Brexit impact and instructions +121% yoy (3156 instructions in August). 65% market share vs online peers. LPE recruitment is ahead of plan (now 300). Australia is “progressing very well”.

12:05 pm
BE

Meanwhile, Anthony Codling at Jefferies continues to question whether "agreeing a sale" means "completing a sale".

BE

Once again Purplebricks has chosen to major on growth in instructions without telling us how many homes it has actually helped to sell, we continue to be surprised that this simple question is left unanswered. The Group describes trading since May as encouraging and in-line with their expectations. We think it a shame that management do not tell us how many homes they hope to ‘sell’ rather than ‘list for sale’ as we expect their customers ultimately are more interested in the selling rather than the listing…

BE

Unlike its high street rivals Purplebricks has seen 'little discernible impact following the EU referendum', this in our view points more to the growth of the Group and increase in Local Property Experts than the markets it serves. Our previous analysis suggested that Purplebricks were not selling many homes before EU referendum, so it may not actually be good news that the EU referendum has had little discernible impact… At 130p Purplebricks is reassuringly expensive trading on a CY17 PER of 114.4x against the sector on 8.9x and offers a yield of 0.3% against the sector on 6.4%

12:07 pm
BE

Scan back in the archive for Mr Codling's analysis, or speak to Jefferies directly. It's the kind of argument that's worth reading, whatever your view on the stock.

undefined
BE

Oh, hey ........

12:07 pm
BE

BANK OF ENGLAND KEEPS KEY INTEREST RATE AT 0.25%; VOTE 9-0

BE

BOE: MPC MAJORITY EXPECT RATE CUT IF AUGUST OUTLOOK CONFIRMED

BE

(Speaking as someone with a tracker mortgage: \o/ )

12:08 pm
BE

And with that, I think we're done.

BE

Didn't get round to mentioning Powerflute .....

BE

Bid from Nordic Packaging and Container, 90p a share.

Here's Davy, to summarise.

12:13 pm
BE

Madison Dearborn has made an improved offer this morning for the outstanding stock of Powerflute through a newly created entity, Bidco. The new cash offer is 90p per share and values the company at c.£268m. The offer has been recommended by the Powerflute Board.

BE

Bidco is a company recently incorporated in Finland by investment funds advised by Madison Dearborn Partners for the purpose of making and implementing the offer. Under the terms of the offer, each shareholder will be entitled to receive 90p in cash which values the company at c.£268m. This represents a premium of c.22% to the closing price of 73.75p per share on September 14th 2016, the last business day prior to the date of the announcement. Bidco has already agreed to acquire c.51% of the issued share capital of Powerflute as a result of undertakings from Smurfit, Henderson Global and Alphagen Capital.
